title: general-election-2019-voting-system-works
story: Unlike the single transferable vote system used in the East Lothian Council elections, FPTP is a straight race to the line, with voters only allowed to vote for one candidate and the candidate with the most votes winning.Voters mark an x on their ballot paper next to the candidate they wish to vote for - they must not mark any of the other candidates boxes or their ballot paper will be spoilt.Once all the votes across the constituency have been tallied, the candidate with the most votes is elected.Voting takes place between am and pm on Thursday, December , with the East Lothian result expected to be declared some time early in the morning, potentially any time between about am and about am, although this is liable to change depending on how close the result is.The final UK-wide result is not expected to be known until well into the Friday morning.The General Election is to elect the UK Government at Westminster, with all  seats across Scotland, England, Wales and Northern Ireland up for grabs.To win a majority, a party would need at least  seats.Traditionally, a General Election is held only once every five years, but this will be the third General Election since May , coming only two and a half years after the last one in June .The last election resulted in a hung parliament, with the Conservatives losing their majority and finishing with  seats, while Labour came second with seats.In Scotland, the SNP won  of the  seats, more than half, although that did represent a loss of  seats from their historic  result. However, it was still enough to see them finish as the third largest party across the UK, well ahead of the fourth-placed Liberal Democrats, who won  seats UK-wide.The Conservatives increased their number of seats in Scotland from one to  to finish second, while Labour and the Liberal Democrats, both of whom also had won only one seat in Scotland in , also made gains, winning seven and four seats respectively.East Lothian, which had been one of a swathe of Labour seats to fall to the SNP in , was one of Labours gains last time around in , Martin Whitfield overturning sitting MP George Kerevans majority of nearly , to regain the seat for Labour with a majority of ,.The Conservatives Sheila Low was a close third, a little over  votes behind the SNP.Unlike in the council elections and the Scottish Parliament elections,  and -year-olds cannot vote in the General Election - voters must be  or over.

title: general-election-2019-statement-east-lothian-constituency-conservative-candidate-craig-hoy
story: East Lothian is the second fastest growing area in Scotland. The speed of development is challenging our schools, our hospitals and GPs surgeries, our roads and our railways. And itrsquos challenging our local environment: the very thing that attracts so many people to live here.So,elected as your MP, I will put East Lothianrsquos infrastructure first ndash and stand firm against any attempt by the SNP to force thousands more homes on East Lothian. This will be my number one priority.Climate change affects us all but it will hit younger residents hardest. As a member of East Lothian Council, I backed the climate change emergency declaration. But itrsquos vital we match words with deeds. As your MP, I will do that. I am committed to promoting a secure and low-carbon-based economy, supporting sustainable local transport and resources across East Lothian.I also want to tackle the scourge of poverty in East Lothian. The best way of lting people out of poverty is to create new, skilled jobs and apprenticeships. Thatrsquos why I will push for more investment to create jobs at the former Cockenzie Power Station site and the new Innovation Park at Queen Margaret University.As your MP, I will work hard for those who work hard. But I will work twice as hard for the poorest and most vulnerable members of our community. I will always stand up for older people and will push for the BBC to reverse its decision to remove free TV licences from the over-s.But we cannot escape one simple fact. The SNP donrsquot see this election as being about East Lothianrsquos future but instead as an opportunity to mount lsquoone final heaversquo for independence. And Jeremy Corbynrsquos Labour Party is ready to help them do it.The SNP wants next year to be the year of two isive referendums. We need to send a clear message to Nicola Sturgeon: we donrsquot want another independence referendum.The only way to do that is to vote Scottish Conservative, because Jeremy Corbynrsquos Labour Party is simply too weak and ided to win here.My position is unambiguous: no s, no buts, no IndyRef.Put simply, I want to go to Westminster to be East Lothianrsquos voice in Parliament, not remove your voice from it.

title: ross-high-school-extension-work-start-christmas
story: The first phase of the planned extension has now been officially approved by East Lothian Council.The extension will host a PE staff base, changing and WC facilities, as well as the main hall and storage area.The hall will be accessed from within the existing school building.A small amount of demolition will take place in order to create the entrance way.Phase two of the extension involves a new teaching block with  new classrooms, housing languages, art, ICT and a social area with a small canteen.The second phase is yet to be formally approved but contractors are due to start building work on both parts of the project after Christmas.Preliminary groundwork at the school has already started.The council set aside pound million out of its five-year capital improvement budget in February for the work, which it is estimated will take about a year.Headteacher Paul Reynolds said: ldquoItrsquos great to see some action after a long planning period.ldquoAfter Christmas, the building work will start.ldquoThe site manager from FES is actually a former Ross High pupil so that means the builders have some extra investment in the school, which is quite nice, and relations have been really good.ldquoThe disruption to the pupils has been very minimal.ldquoI would like to thank enjoyleisure and the Loch Centre for allowing us to use their facilities to host some of our PE classes at our busiest times of the week.ldquoThe pupils and staff have also been great and very flexible.

title: prestonpans-teenager-auditions-x-factor-band
story: In the new show, which began airing on Monday, Simon Cowell is searching for the next big British group.Louis Robertson, , of Nethershot Road, sang George Ezrarsquos Blame It On Me in a filmed audition in front of Simon Cowell, Nicole Scherzinger and a  of experts, one whom he recognised as the DJ Naughty Boy, at Sony Musicrsquos head office in London.Louis, who works at Scottish Widows, did not get through to the next stage of the competition but was delighted to have been picked to perform in front of the judges.He got a call on the Sunday night from the show producers after his mum and girlfriend filled in an application for him and sent off a video of him performing.The former Preston Lodge High School pupil said: ldquoI got a phone call askingI would like to go to an audition last Tuesday in London.ldquoI got time off my work and took the night bus down on the Monday night. title: historic-musselburgh-ice-cream-business-di-rollo-sale
story: The -year-old business has a shop on Bridge Street and ice cream factoryon South Street.But the owners of thebusiness, which was established in  and has been in the Di Rollo family ever since, will soon be retiring and are hoping that someone will take on the business.Independent Scottish chartered surveyorGraham + Sibbald is acting on behalf of theice cream manufacturer and wholesaler around the sale of the business.Di Rollo supplies a large selection of flavoured ice cream to many restaurants, cafes, hotels, catering companies and retail outlets across East Lothian and Edinburgh.The business includes a purpose-built production facility and the premises covers over , square feet.Graham + Sibbald say that the facility complies with all the latest EU directives and is capable of producing over  litres of ice cream an hour.Suzanne Lawrie, business valuer at Graham + Sibbald, said: ldquoDi Rollo Ice Cream is a much loved, successful regional business with a fantastic customer base."As a third-generation, family-run business, the current owners are planning their retirement and this underpins the decision to sell."We see this as an excellent opportunity to expand the business.

title: second-platform-dunbar-railway-station-opens-sunday

title: tims-tales-dont-quick-judge
story: A COMBINATION of ill health, a current inability to walk without knee pain and dark winter nights have conspired recently to keep me in the house and away from the joys of exploring my favourite places in nature.I have not been housebound, but I have had a taste of the feeling of being so. It is a scary premonition.ldquoYoursquore just getting old, was a recent diagnosis from a family member! It was said with affection, of course, yet the ring of truth gave it an unhelpful sting. Age, of course, is just a number and state of mind and I have much to keep me youthful.What did help was meeting up with an old friend last week. As we sat together sharing memories of our youth and the shenanigans we got up to  years ago, I had a disorientating sense of time. It seemed impossible that so many years had passed since the moments we remembered had taken place. Those moments were so present for us. As another clicheacute says, it was asit was yesterday.We both complimented each other on how young we looked but I think this was because we both saw the younger person underneath the wrapping made by time. Society judges so much by appearance, we all do. But when we meet an old friend, even when we have not been in touch for many years, we see the person we knew, eventhe exterior has changed. As the philosopher Henry David Thoreau once said: ldquoItrsquos not what you look at that matters, itrsquos what you see.Who can say honestly they have not judged someone because of what they look like  I am as guilty as anyone . As I said, we all do it on the bus, in the queue at the supermarket while we wait our turn, everywhere. We glimpse at people, avoiding eye contact, but making immediate judgement on the way they look. Sometimes itrsquos negative, sometimes envious, sometimes positive and admiring but always superficial. And I know, like everyone , I too am likewise judged.Itrsquos a human habit, perhaps a primeval instinct in which we must quickly judge people for our safety. But of course outward appearance gives no clue to someonersquos character and real qualities. We must know something of that person first before we can judge on that.And this means seeing beyond what we look at. And to do this we need eye contact, a smile, a friendly gesture and the exchange of some words. We need to connect to the person inside. And the irony is, while there are more of us than ever sharing ever-bigger spaces, we are ever more disconnected from each other.The truth Irsquove come to realise is that you donrsquot have to be an old friend with someone to see their inner self, you just need to see beyond what appears to you. We have another primeval instinct and that is to detect the warmth of a character. But we cannot do thatwe only see what we look at and make no attempt to connect.My resolution, even before New Year, is to do this more often. To smile, say some friendly words and not judge or assume things. I think we actually all need more of this, with people we donrsquot know as much as those we do.As someone once said, a stranger is a friend you havenrsquot met yet. Well maybe you have, but you just havenrsquot spoken to them or really seen them for who they are.

title: hometown-clubs-special-honour-golf-star-catriona-matthew
story: They gave Catriona, who is from the town, the membership in celebration of her victorious Solheim Cup captaincy at this yearrsquos competition, which was held at Gleneagles in September.Stuart Martin, golf operations manager at North Berwick Golf Club, said: ldquoThe club was absolutely delighted when she was given the [Solheim Cup] captaincy.ldquoEveryone was delighted for her when she won the Solheim Cup, especially since she has been related to North Berwick Golf Club for so many years.ldquoGiving her the honorary le membership was a no-brainer ndash everyone was delighted for it to go through.Catriona has been a member of North Berwick Golf Club since , when she was just  years old.On Catrionarsquos reaction to being given the honorary le membership, Stuart added: ldquoShe was just delighted and thanked everyone for being there.ldquoShe talked a little bit about her history growing up playing on the West Links, which led to her going on to do bigger and better things on the European Tour and her experience at the Solheim Cup.The club also announced it was renaming its East Lounge, located on the top floor of the clubhouse, the Catriona Matthew Lounge.Mr Martin added: ldquoShe was a little bit shocked to hear we were renaming the lounge after her.ldquoShersquos quite a private person and keeps herself to herself but she was delighted to receive both of these recognitions.

title: consultation-proposed-transport-hub-haddington-branded-shambolic
story: Protests are expected to take place outside Haddington Town House on Monday evening when the proposals are put to the public.And angry business owners are also planning to place banners outside the townrsquos General Election polling station at the Aubigny Centre today .In recent weeks, East Lothian Council has repeatedly changed plans for a public consultation on a controversial proposal for a new car park east of the town centre. One business owner accused the local authority of trying to ide and confuse people so they did not attend.It comes after the council:Haddington Business Community Partnership had asked the council to postpone the public consultation until the start of the new year because it believes the local authority has breached Scottish Government guidelines stating that consultation exercises should not be launched during local or national election periods.A spokesperson for the council has denied this is the case and insisted it is a normal part of pre-consultation process.Community councillor Pat Lemmon said the decisions of the council were disappointing.She said: ldquoIt does not encourage feelings of trust for everyone working together. The ground rules change by the day.And she said the councilrsquos handling of the proposals had caused major distrust among residents, particularly when it came to the independently produced Haddington Vision document officials use to support their case.She said: ldquoThe Haddington Vision strongly said any changes had to be looked at by all the stakeholders, by everyone concerned, to avoid any ill feeling, to make everyone feel they had been consulted as part of proposed plans.ldquoThe statement made that East Lothian Council hopes to be in a position to implement a decision by March  indicates to me that there appears to be a race on to secure funding for the transportation hub.ldquoIf this is the case, is this the right decision given the strong views for and against any proposed hub in the town and the proposed town centre plans currently being discussed by the steering group ldquoTo have such a meeting so close to Christmas, and the stakeholder consultation at a time when many people are working, seems to me to be a bad decision.ldquoI am very disappointed that such a decision has been made.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council previously confirmed that the drop-in event would run -pm, with a public notice in the Courier of November  confirming that was the case.The event was to give local residents and businesses ldquothe opportunity to discover more about the proposals for a transport hub in Haddington.She said: ldquoThey will also be able to see the progress and history of the project to date, including the consideration of  dferent sites across the town.ldquoComments can be recorded as part of this consultation which will help inform the future development of the proposal and will be followed by another consultation in the New Year.However, the public section of the event has been reduced to just  minutes.When asked why the format of the event had been changed, the spokeswoman said: ldquoDue to a combination of level of interest and availability of staff, a stakeholders meeting will be held at pm and invitees include local business owners, schools, community council, sports clubs, transport companies and accessibility and active travel interests. [The] public event will start at pm.Other sites considered for the car park and dropped for ldquoious reasons include the field between West Road, Park Lane, Pencaitland Road and Letham Drive, and the site of the former Haddington Nursery School Annexe, off Meadowpark, which has also been earmarked for a housing development.The plans for Whittingehame Drive, which were drawn up following a series of closed door meetings, came under fire from a number of Haddington residents.Concerns ranged from the loss of green space on the site, which is beside the townrsquos skate park and G sports pitches, to the potential for accidents with youngsters playing next to the car park.The transport hub, which would include a car park with somewhere between  and  spaces, could also include ldquobus connections, bike hire opportunities and new pathways.According to East Lothian Council, the facility,approved, has ldquothe potential to free up parking spaces in the town for short-stay use, making it easier for people to access local businesses, essential services and tourist attractions.However, business owners were among those raising concerns about the proposals.George James, who runs the East Lothian TV and Video Repair Centre on High Street, felt that the last-minute changes were an attempt by the council to ide people.He said: ldquoIt is clearly isive and an effort to stop people attending the public consultations.ldquoWe are a local business and have been told we cannot attend the stakeholdersrsquo meeting as we are not considered stakeholders.ldquoWe are encouraging as many people as possible to join a protest at the Town House on Monday evening we are determined to ensure they do not get away with this approach, which appears shambolic.Karla Green from the shop is handing out leaflets advising people about the public meeting but the times have changed so much even her leaflets are now out of date.She said: ldquoThey still have pm on them so we have to tell everyone that the time has changed ndash again.Project consultants WYG will be in attendance on Monday and will have a number of display boards showing the extent of proposals.Council transport officers will also be in the Town House and people will have the opportunity to ask questions.A council spokesperson said: ldquoThe public lsquodrop-inrsquo part is now -.pm and it has been extended due to securing availability of key members of the project team being available to answer public questions.ldquoInvitations to the stakeholdersrsquo meeting are for two representatives from a range of organisations involved in business transport in Haddington and confirmed invitees include Haddington Business Community Partnership, Haddington Community Development Trust, East Coast Buses, Prentice Coaches, Lothian Buses.

title: pair-travel-10k-wheelchairs-help-day-centre
story: Megan Roland from Gford and Joanne Rye from Ormiston both completed the k journey from Ormiston to Tranent and back with help from their support workers.Through sponsorship they raised pound for Ormistonrsquos Primrose Day Centre.Megan, , and Joanne, , have support needs and have required the use of wheelchairs all their lives.They duo had assistance on the trek from their support workers Catherine Mitchell and Jackie Hoy.Joanne told the Courier: ldquoIt was exciting because Jackie, Megan and Cath did it with me and my niece and sister came along too.ldquoWe did it for Alzheimerrsquos as my mum has it and I wanted to do it for the Primrose Day Centre as she goes there.ldquoIt was a very successful and very fun sponsored walk.Megan and Joanne used to live together until Megan moved out to a house of her own.They have been on holidays together, including one memorable trip to Blackpool.

title: talented-ross-high-school-pupil-reaches-futurechef-finals
story: Bartek Kocot, an S pupil at the school, cooked up a winning meal for judges and will now represent East Lothian at the regional level of the competition, organised by Springboard FutureChef to inspire young people to cook.Bartek was chosen to represent Ross High at the heat because of the standard of his cooking in class and his efforts to practise dishes outside of school hours.He competed against four other pupils at the school in their own heat, then in round two competed at an event at Edinburgh College, Granton Campus last Thursday against pupils from secondary schools in Edinburgh and the Lothians.The dishes were judged by professional chefs Glyn Stevens, Stephen Frost and David Bell.Due to his success, he will now compete in the penultimate round of the competition ndash the regional finals, which will take place in Glasgow on February  ndash ahead of the national finals, which are held in London later next year.His dishes were: herb and panko crusted cod with mashed potato, sweet potato with a parmesan crisp and berry poached pear with cookie snap biscuit and cream cheese.Jenner Hart, home economics teacher at the school, said: ldquoWe are all so proud of Bartek, especially as he designed the dessert himself.ldquoThe judges normally only choose one pupil out of Edinburgh and the Lothians however, they said that the standard of dishes was so high that they decided to choose Bartek from East Lothian and Katie from Castlebrae Community High to represent Edinburgh City.ldquoThey said they were very impressed and that they have never seen such a high standard of dishes at the local final.ldquoWe were lucky enough to have executive training chef from the Apex Hotel John Newton as Bartekrsquos mentor so thank you to him for all his expertise and support.Ross High headteacher Paul Reynolds said: ldquoI am thrilled for Bartek. He really put his all into the local finals and it was great to see this pay off.ldquoI would also like to thank his teacher, Jen Hart, who supported him so well throughout the process. We wish Bartek the best of luck in the regional finals.

title: blindwells-confirmed-name-east-lothians-new-town
story: Six names had been shortlisted for the new town being created at the former opencast mine at Blindwells, between Tranent and Longniddry.East Lothian Council had initiallysaid it wanted a "new name for a new town" and asked school pupils to help it compile a shortlist.However, the move brought anger from some areas of the local community, who believed the settlement should retain the name of Blindwells.The full list of names put out to public consultation was:Blindwells, Charlestoun, Hattonfield, Hopetoun, Muirdale and Nethermuir.A meeting of East Lothian Council in Haddington this morningheard that  per cent of those taking part in the consultation had stated that Blindwells was their preference for the name of the new town.Council officials therefore recommended approving Blindwells as the towns name and this was unanimously agreed by councillors.Planning permission for the first , houses at the site has already been granted and groundwork is under way.

title: huge-efforts-put-christmas-lunch-thousands-school-pupils
story: A staggering  kilos of locally grown Brussels sprouts and nearly  kilos of potatoeswill need to be peeled and prepared ahead of the festive meals.More than , pupils will be tucking into a festive meal ahead of December  with an estimated  kilos of turkey and  kilos of carrots also on the menu.And it will all be washed down with  litres of gravy.East Lothian Councilrsquos catering team picked up the Soil Association Scotlandrsquos Bronze Food for Le Served Here award for its commitment to serving fresh and sustainable meals using local produce.Their commitment is reflected with both  kilos of locally-grown potatoes and  kilos of sprouts on this yearrsquos festive menu.Out of the countyrsquos , schools roll, it is expected that , pupils will opt for a Christmas lunch this year.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, council cabinet spokesperson for education and childrenrsquos services, said: ldquoThe school Christmas lunch is a lovely occasion in the end-of-term calendar and much-enjoyed by pupils.ldquoItrsquos important to ensure that we provide this for all our pupils in the run-up to Christmas."Our school catering teams work closely with trusted local suppliers to make sure the meals we serve are good for the pupils and good for the local farming community too.ldquoIrsquod like to commend them for theefforts that they put into providing an award-winning service all year round and the special efforts they make to supporting Christmas celebrations in our schools.

title: parking-plans-dunbar-unveiled
story: Discussions between East Lothian Council and ious parties to try to add spaces to the town and improve the general flow of traffic are ongoing. Among the steps being considered is the creation of a -space car park between Woodbush and Church Street.Furthermore, the councilrsquos transportation team is looking at the possibility of extending the car park at the railway station, which has  spaces, while potentially putting time restrictions on the car park at Abbeylands, which is home to more than  spaces.A planning application for the new car park, which would be accessed by Lamer Street and Woodbush, has been submitted by the local authority to its own planning department.The car park, which is described as being on land adjacent to the Coastguard Cottages, could also provide parking for the nearby Assembly Rooms, which have long been earmarked for development.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoThe proposed car park is promoted to meet demand and to compensate for future road space enhancement within Dunbar town centre. It has also previously been identied that the Coastguard site could potentially provide parking for any new flats in the Assembly Rooms.A metal staircase linking the car park to the adjacent Church Street and the town centre is also included as part of the proposals.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, had mixed thoughts on the scheme.She said: ldquoLargely, there is a demand for parking.ldquoHowever, these car parking spaces would require traffic to move past a very small group of cottages that have enjoyed a degree of privacy in effectively a cul-de-sac all the time they have been there.ldquoInitial messages I have had from residents are of horror.ldquoThe prospect is that green space will be tarmacked over and become a pretty signicant car parking lot.The spokeswoman for the local authority highlighted the proposed car park was part of a wider project surrounding parking in the town.She said: ldquoThe project that transportation is considering has nothing to do with the Assembly Rooms but rather a straight forward look at available space to act as long stay and to change Abbeylands parking to short stay.ldquoThe council is currently negotiating with Transport Scotland and Network Rail to increase the capacity of the rail station car park to stop indiscriminate parking on local streets. This site provides an opportunity to add some additional supply into the town to encourage parking behaviour that is more appropriate.Councillor Norman Hampshire, who represents the Dunbar and East Linton ward, was unable to comment on the specics of the proposals as he is convener of the councilrsquos planning committee. But he said but said there was a need to address parking problems in the town.He said: ldquoThe old part of the town, the narrow streets around Church Street and Castle Street, is very congested with the number of cars parked there because of the restrictions on the High Street. Traders and people who work in the premises park on the surrounding streets and they are very congested.There is definitely a need for more parking in the town centre.Councillor Paul McLennan, who also represents the town, is not part of the planning committee and welcomed the possibility of a car park being created. He highlighted some neighbouring streets had a number of parked cars on them and this could reduce that.He said: ldquoIf you go along Church Street in Dunbar, there is very little parking.

title: plans-rocket-engine-testing-site-turned
story: Skyroras bid to set up a base on the former coal handling plant at Port Seton had caused a ision between neighbouring community councils and saw nearly  objections lodged with East Lothian Council.And at a meeting of the local authoritys planning committee today , the proposal was rejected against the advice of council officials after planning convenor Councillor Norman Hampshire branded the development a "bad neighbour".Mr Hampshire told fellow committee members that he was concerned that allowing Skyrora to test rockets on the land, which is central to the councils future economic plans, could put other investors off.He said: "This is not a good neighbour ndash it is a bad neighbour development and my concern is this may deter potential investors from taking on development at the Cockenzie site."Skyrora had lodged an application to create a rocket engine testing site on the land, which is owned by the local authority, with plans to carry out five -second tests each month.But while they applied for temporary use of the site for five years, they told the planning committee they envisaged the possibility of not just expanding their presence in the community but potentially bringing a manufacturing facility, described as the size of an Ikea outlet, to Cockenzie.And while Prestonpans Community Council, which lies on the boundary of the site, supported their move as offering potential for jobs and the economy, Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council objected.At the planning committee meeting this week, Bryan Hickman, from Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council, pointed to a public meeting which had seen between  and  people turn out.He said: "Virtually everyone who was there was against it ranging from our youngest residents to pensioners. The feeling, rightly or wrongly, in the community is that they do not want it."During the planning meeting local residents raised concerns about the storage of key elements of fuel on the site for days prior to testing as well as the impact of burning kerosene into the atmosphere.While Skyrora insisted the engine tests would be a "clean burn" producing mainly water, resident and biochemist Dr Brian Hall told the committee that he estimated around , litres of carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide could be released during each  second test.Calum Miller, on behalf of Prestonpans Community Council, urged councillors to approve the plans pointing out that the power station site had lain empty now for six years.He told them: "The council has the opportunity with this Skyrora application to dispel the myth that we are too remote from Edinburgh to attract business."However ward councillors Fiona ODonnell, Lachlan Bruce and Neil Gilbert all refused to vote in favour of planning approval.Councillor ODonnell said that the impact on local amenity would be unacceptable and spoke of the "high level of public concern" from constituents about the proximity of the test site to housing ndash the nearest of which was estimated at  metres away.The plans were rejected by six councillors to two.

title: lanterne-rouge-cafe-now-well-versed-great-poetry
story: Stella Hervey Birrell was unveiled as the poet-in-residence at Gfordrsquos Lanterne Rouge cafe at the beginning of the year.One task she set out to achieve was to create a collection of poems based around a particular theme.She invited submissions to an anthology ndash Lanterne Rouge: The Last ndash with dozens of budding poets getting in touch with their writings based on the theme of lsquothe lastrsquo.The cafe, on the villagersquos Main Street, takes its name after the award given to the last-placed cyclist in the Tour de France, referencing how a red lantern used to hang on the back of passenger trains.Ms Hervey Birrell was delighted to say the event had been a great success, with money raised from the project going to St Columbarsquos Hospice.She said: ldquoCameron McVean [who runs the cafe] fundraises for St Columbarsquos every year.ldquoIt was completely natural that it would be sold for charity and that they would be the charity.ldquoI am slightly obsessive about paying poets ndash they never get paid for anything ndash and we did a kickstarter campaign, which paid them and covered the printing costs.ldquoI thought of the name of the cafe ndash Lanterne Rouge ndash and I had no idea what it meant. I thought it was great to ask for submissions on lsquoThe Lastrsquo and we got a real wide range.The appeal for poetry caught the attention of the wider public, with East Lothian residents and beyond getting in touch with Ms Hervey Birrell, who lives in Pencaitland, with poems.The -year-old said: ldquoThere are  poems in the anthology, with two by local primary school children. I went into Yester Primary School to do a workshop and a few submitted to me.ldquoThere were quite a lot of folk from Edinburgh and further afield. It was an open submission and there were  or so to choose from.Readings from the anthology, which is available from the cafe and other outlets in Gford, took place as the collection was launched at the end of last month.A fundraising auction also took place, with items including a cottage stay and a flag from last yearrsquos Ryder Cup, which was signed by both captains, as well as a raffle.Mr McVean told the Courier the idea of a poet-in-residence came about as ldquoa random notion.He said: ldquoI think it was Dumbarton Football Club who had a poet-in-residence. I thoughtthey can have one, why canrsquot we

title: scottish-cup-dream-edges-closer-haddington-athletic
story: The East of Scotland Football League side has been given permission to install floodlights at Millfield.The move allows the club to move closer to gaining its Scottish Football Associationlicence, which would open the door to the club playing in the Scottish Cup and also moving up the league pyramid.Drew Donaldson, first team chairman, was pleased with the progress being made, with a decision likely to be taken by Scottish footballrsquos governing body in February as to whether the ground is up to the standard required for the countryrsquos premier cup competition. Celtic FC are the current holders.He said: ldquoWe are still hopeful we will make the deadline in February.ldquoIt does seem a bit surreal ndash I never thought we would have floodlights at Millfield.East Lothian Council gave the football club, which dates back  years, planning permission for the installation of eight floodlights.The floodlights, which measure  metres in height, would be put in place around the grass pitch, with four each side of the park.Currently, only Preston Athletic represent East Lothian in the Scottish Cup, with the Pennypit side having taken on Queenrsquos Park and Montrose in recent years, as well as knocking Stenhousemuir out of the competition in .In recent months, Tranent Juniors and Musselburgh Athletic have also received permission to erect floodlights at their grounds.Mr Donaldson said: ldquoIf you look at the coverage the likes of Bonnyrigg Rose and Penicuik Athletic got a few weeks ago in the Scottish Cup, it shows what is possible.ldquoWe are not a million miles away from Penicuik and you see clubs can get a few breaks.Mr Donaldson highlighted the prize money on offer through the Scottish Cup, with clubs gaining money for reaching each round, as well as the possibility of cup ties being shown on national television.Floodlights are expected to cost in the region of pound,, with half of the five-figure sum coming from East Lothian Council.The planning officerrsquos report notes that the installation of floodlights would allow the facilities at Millfield to be used for longer periods and that they could be used up to pm Monday to Friday during the winter and up to pm over the weekend.

title: man-flashed-barmaid-told-leave-pub
story: Finlay MacDonald, , unfastened his trousers and exposed his genitals after refusing to leave the townrsquos Golfers Rest pub in August this year.MacDonald acted in a disorderly manner and refused to leave the premises when asked to do so by staff member Carol Ann Widdowson.He then dropped his trousers so Ms Widdowson would intentionally see his genitals while also handling them during the disturbing incident.MacDonald, of Lime Grove, denied the allegations and stood trial at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Friday.Sherf John Cook heard the evidence of the case and, following witness testimonies, he found MacDonald guilty of two charges.The sherf fined MacDonald pound for behaving in a disorderly manner and told him he must pay Ms Widdowson pound in compensation.MacDonald was also banned from entering the Golfers Rest, on the townrsquos High Street, for the next two years following the incident on August .The exposure charge was reduced to a breach of the peace offence, meaning MacDonald avoided being placed on the sex offendersrsquo register.

title: community-shelter-bid-town-centre
story: The shelter in the Lodge was the idea of  young people from North Berwick Youth Project and North Berwick High Schoolrsquos Princersquos Trust group.Work started on the project last year when it was highlighted that there were few locations in the town where the youngsters felt safe.With help from staff at the youth project, the group carried out a consultation.They asked members of the public and those who use the youth project to choose which locations were best for shelters.The results were overwhelmingly in favour of the Lodge Grounds, with a second shelter on the east side of Quality Street ndash near to the townrsquos public toilets and across the street from the North Berwick Fry ndash also on the wishlist.The shelter in the Lodge has now been built ndash but the prospect of a similar structure in the town centre is still in the very early planning stages.Lauren Cowie, of North Berwick Youth Project, said: ldquoThere used to be three shelters in the Lodge Grounds but none of these exist at all now.ldquoI hope young people are going to use it [the Lodge Grounds shelter], but I also hope everyone will use it and want to use it as well. The shelter is for everyone and they can use it for a iety of things, such as meeting up or escaping the rain to read a book.Volunteers from Glasclune Gardens offered their help alongside East Lothian Council, who helped build it.Lauren was pleased to see work start on the Lodge Grounds shelter, which includes seating, in recent weeks.She said: ldquoAll of a sudden, [East Lothian Council] said they were just going to start building it.ldquoWe have had some issues along the way which held us back slightly. We were lucky to get pound, from the area partnership and we asked for pound, more for lighting.ldquoThe lighting was going to be linked to the street lighting that already exists but we donrsquot have the budget to be paying a bill every month.ldquoAs lighting wasnrsquot possible, we decided to place it near the street lights and hope they will provide enough light. If we get feedback saying it is too dark or more lighting needs to be put in place, we will certainly look at that.The shelter is the same design as one installed in Garvald last year.The youth project is planning to place a plaque on the shelter and is looking for name suggestions which can be sent to Lauren at lauren.cowie@northberwickyouthprojectMeanwhile, the youth project is keen to progress plans for a similar shelter on Quality Street.It is likely a second public consultation exercise will be held before any planning application is submitted.Lauren said that the group had been focusing its attention on the shelter in the Lodge Grounds but now that that project was almost complete they would look to have architectural drawings created to show how a town centre shelter could look.Judy Lockhart, chair of the townrsquos community council, said: ldquoThe community council is aware the youth project is considering a shelter on Quality Street. We will discuss the plans in due course.ldquoIf residents have comments or feedback they would like us to consider, these should be sent to our secretary Kathryn Smith at secretary@northberwickcommunitycouncil.org.uk

title: east-lothian-bin-collection-times-christmas-new-year

title: tims-tales-marcelas-christmas
story: IN A VILLAGE, many years ago in a country far from us, yet also close, it once snowed, then it snowed some more.Christmas was approaching and the children of the village were outside playing, building snowmen, making snow angels, having snowball fights and sledging down the hill.Marcela watched from her bedroom window. Her wee brother Pavel was having lots of fun. She waved at him and he waved back, throwing a snowball at the window, then rejoining his friends.Marcela ed to her book. She loved reading, it was her escape into other worlds. She could not enjoy the snow like her wee brother, for she had been in a wheelchair for all her le and the chair would stick in the snow.It was possible to go outside with help, especially when her father was home, butshe tried it herself the front wheels would stick in the snow and ice.It was humiliating so she preferred to stay inside with her books and imagination. But she read by the window, watching her brother and class mates having fun.Then a robin landed on the window sill. It seemed to stare at Marcela. She looked at the wee bird and smiled.ldquoLucky you she said ldquoI wish I had your freedom and that I could fly like you.The little birdrsquos head turned to its side asit was saying something. Then it flew away.Soon after it was December , the day Christmas was celebrated in these parts, and presents were given. There was not a pile expensive gts, but a few simple ones and always one specially unusal present for each child.The family were poor, but anticipation of what the unusual gt would be was always a highlight of Christmas.Pavel opened his first. As he unwrapped it his eyes gleamed with excitement.ldquoYes! he called out, hugging his mother and father. It was a huge bottle of ketchup, the real stuff! That may not sound such a present, but it was not easy to get this kind of ketchup in the village and he had always had to use it sparingly. Now he had this bottle all to himself.Then Marcela open her unusual present. She smiled as she held two unusual looking carved short planks of wood, unsure initially what they were. Then she smiled.ldquoAw perfect, bookends for my shelf.ldquoThere are not bookends, said her father. Marcela looked at them again. ldquoOh, what are they then Her father took them and went to her wheelchair. He connected them to the front wheels of the chair.ldquoThey are wheelchair skis, he said, ldquoI made them. Marcela was overwhelmed.Within ten minutes, Marcela was wrapped up and ready to go out. She nervously wheeled her chair onto the snow covered front path. Usually the wheels would stick within seconds, but this time her chair slid effortlessly along the path.Soon she had got the hang of manoeuvring the chair in the snow. She had snow ball fight and was able to spin around and chase her schoolmates while storing lots of ammunition on her lap.Then she decided she wanted to sledge down the hill. With some help from her brother she got to the top of the hill and peered down the slope. Her classmates had gathered round her wonderingshersquod really do it. She edged forward and then reached the point of no . The wheelchair slid down the slope, faster and faster. Marcela raised her hands like wings crying out ldquowheeee look at me.Then the chair slowed as it approached the bottom on the hill and wobbled to and fro. A bank of snow toppled the chair throwing Marcela out and she fell face first into the snow, arms outstretched.Her brother ran to her and helped her back into the chair. Marcelarsquos face was red with the cold and her eyes tearful. They were tears of joy and laughter.ldquoLook, she said pointing to her shape in the snow ldquoIrsquove made a snow angel!All that Christmas day, Marcela played in the snow with her brother and classmates, even making new friends. She became expert at flying down the hill in her chair.That night Pavel tried to take his bottle of ketchup to bed with him. But he was persuaded the fridge would be a better idea.And as Marcela was falling asleep, the little robin reappeared in the moonlight on her window sill. She smiled at the bird.ldquoIt was the best Christmas ever, she said.ldquoI got my freedom and today I learnt to fly.

title: dunbar-resident-starts-christmas-kindness-campaign-help-others
story: Demi-Lee Taylor, , of Bayswell Road, started a kindness campaign called The Peoplersquos Christmas Miracle, which aims to support families, the elderly and the homeless in East Lothian at Christmas.She asked people to donate clothes, baby items, toys and food to help those in need.The mum-of-two was moved to act in light of her own experiences and from hearing of the problems faced by others.Demi, who is a le coach and an author who writes books for the terminally ill, said: ldquoI have been approached by parents in the school playground who say their children are having to go into school without breakfast some are being bullied because they canrsquot afford to go on school trips.ldquoI hear the elderly limit their food and heating and the homeless are left out in the cold.ldquoI donrsquot believe anyone should suffer, especially at Christmas time. Itrsquos a time for family and friends to get together, no one should be left out.ldquoMany of our elderly and homeless are ex-soldiers and it makes me wonder why the people who fought for our country are just left to live this way.ldquoPoverty in families in this day and age shouldnrsquot exist. Foodbanks are overstretched because so many people are turning to them now for help.ldquoOur children are the next generation and shouldnrsquot be forced into poverty.Demi-Lee used to be on Universal Credit and has seen the impact it has had on todayrsquos society.She added: ldquoIf parents work but still have to claim Universal Credit to bump up their income, theyrsquore told that they earn over the threshold so canrsquot get help. I strongly believe this is how bullying starts because some families can afford things while others canrsquot.And she added: ldquoI came from a poor family: my parents struggled every single day but we got by. It was hard but they managed it and they always gave us a brilliant Christmas.ldquoSome people are embarrassed to ask for help but they shouldnrsquot be. If I can help them I will.One hour after setting up her Facebook page, she was receiving messages and donations from all over East Lothian.She said: ldquoItrsquos amazing to see the community coming together and helping people.ldquoI canrsquot believe the support and reaction, it has been amazing and it is nice to see there are still nice people out there.Demi is holding a bake sale in the Co-op on Dunbarrsquos Countess Crescent from noon on Sunday.And she is also preparing a dinner for  elderly and homeless people on Christmas Day in Dunbar Parish Church.Demi wants to continue her work every Christmas, and hopes it expands beyond East Lothian in future.

title: tranent-youngsters-collect-120-bags-food-foodbank
story: Brothers Archie, , and Finlay Strang, , and their friend Lucas Leishman, , handed out more than  letters to homes in the townrsquos New Row, Edinburgh Road, Market View, Polson Gardens, Bankpark Crescent and Bankpark Grove asking for donations.The younger boys are pupils at Sandersonrsquos Wynd Primary School and Finlay attends Ross High School.They were over the moon at the response of residents who left out more than  shopping bags full of food for them to take to Tranent Libraryrsquos drop-off point for the foodbank.After someone posted one of the letters on social media, the boys were also inundated with requests to pick up food from other locations in Tranent and received an additional  bags.This is the third year that Archie has been collecting for the foodbank.Last year his friend Lucas got involved and Finlay joined their efforts this year.On social media there were dozens of comments praising the actions of the three boys, who were able to collect more than double the amount of food this year than they had managed last year. Raymond Strang, dad to Archie and Finlay, said that he still had a car full of food and more bags to collect from people who had contacted him on social media.He said: ldquoThe boys tried to thank every person personally for making their donation, with Archie saying he is really happy that people in Tranent have continued to support his foodbank appeal.ldquoEvery time they saw someone had left out a bag they were so happy, it was like a gt to them.ldquoThe people we met were so kind to us and Archie hoped that their efforts would help to bring some joy to those who were most in need.ldquoLucas said that everyone he met whilst doing the collection was really nice and it made him really happy to know that he was helping people.ldquoAnd Finlay said that he couldnrsquot believe how much food was being contributed and hoped that next year they could send out more letters to cover more areas. The Tranent people are always so generous and were really kind and complimentary when we thanked them.Foodbank manager Peter Dicker said: ldquoThis was a tremendous effort by three young men showing the pride they have in their own community.ldquoIt was fantastic that they managed to collect so much food for people in the county.ldquoOnce again, East Lothian Foodbank is absolutely astounded by the generosity of people in East Lothian and Tranent in particular.

title: new-look-scottish-seabird-centre-opens-weekend
story: The visitor attraction boasts new mechanical exhibits, interactive games, storyboards and a virtual reality experience.There is also an upgrade to the popular Bass Rock interactive cameras, which show live action from the home of the worldrsquos largest northern gannet colony.All of the elements within the experience have been designed in partnership with a team from Glasgow Science Centre.The Seabird Centre says its new Discovery Experience aims to ldquotransport visitors of all ages from the warmth and comfort of the centre deep into a iety of Scottish marine habits.Focus is on the themes of seabirds, marine habitats and wildle, threats and scientic discovery.It also examines the wonders of marine habitats and the challenges they face, from climate change to marine plastics.The refurbishment also saw upgrades to the centrersquos education centre, cafe and retail space.Susan Davies, CEO of the Seabird Centre, said: ldquoOur refurbishment programme has been both exciting and challenging.ldquoWe are thrilled with the overall refresh of all our exhibits as this strengthens our capability for telling the story of Scotlandrsquos marine environment to erse audiences.ldquo sees us celebrate both our th anniversary, and Scotlandrsquos Year of Coasts and Waters, with a transformed visitor and educational experience.ldquoScotlandrsquos marine environment is exceptional and erse. There is a growing awareness of both its importance and the pressures it is under ndash not least from climate change, invasive species, underwater noise and marine pollution.ldquoOur seas provide vital natural services for society including climate regulation, food provision, renewable energy, scientic discovery and education opportunities. It is important people are aware of its importance and the need to protect it and to use the resources it provides in a sustainable way.ldquoWe look forward to welcoming visitors back to the centre. We hope we will inspire them to embrace the societal changes needed to ensure our marine environment remains healthy and wildle-rich for generations to come.One lucky visitor managed to get an exclusive preview of the centrersquos new Discovery Experience.Pamela Newby, of North Berwick, visited with friends and family last Friday.The -year-old mum-of-two said: ldquoIt is fantastic to see the new-look Scottish Seabird Centrersquos Discovery Experience. The children were all enthralled by the iety of video games and puzzles.ldquoIt was absolutely amazing to be transported to the Bass Rock to roam among the gannets, then swim through the ocean with whales and porpoises using virtual reality. It is a great fun way to introduce children to our marine environment and teach them the importance of protecting it for generations to come.The Discovery Experience officially reopens to the public on Saturday.

title: christmas-gift-minefield-tv-extras-toilet-meddling
story: According to Winkleman: "There are lists, there are panics, theres an eight-year-old who cries because the Barbie isnt the right Barbie. You open a weird candlestick holder in the shape of a watermelon and dont have the heart to ask your cousinshe kept the receipt."Bah humbug, I hear you cry. Well, that was my knee-jerk reaction too. But then the penny dropped: she makes an excellent point.When you think about it, the exchange of Christmas presents is akin to psychological warfare. For a start, there are the eyewatering costs coupled with the anxiety of finding that perfect, heartfelt gt.Then comes plastering on a "Wow, I-truly-love-this-utterly-naff-whatever-it-is" expression after unwrapping a heinous offering, while frantically racking your brains to fathom what on Earth you did to offend that particular person.One of my all-time favourite stories of Christmas presents gone badly awry is the woman who received the baffling gt of three sponges from her husband. "I was told blue was for washing the car, green for the bathroom and pink for the dog," she lamented.Other festive crackers ndash or should that be turkeys  ndash include stretch-mark cream a tin of hamburgers a second-hand broken vacuum cleaner a medley of saucepans a dusty bath set with the previous recipients name-tag still attached and a diary three years out of date.: Susan Swarbrick: Pet portraits, erotic fiction and weird hotel theftsHow ungrateful, I hear you chide, its the thought that counts. Well, indeed,the thought happens to be: "Hold my beer while I nonchalantly offer up a gt-wrapped oddity that I spent less time choosing than I did tying my shoelaces this morning."A face for radioARE you hirsute, missing copious teeth, inhabit either an absurdly large or small body and possess a face that resembles a shrivelled raisin crossed with a battered, leather handbag Then book your ticket to New Zealand where a glittering career awaits as a TV extra. Casting agents for the upcoming, big-budget Lord of the Rings television series are desperately seeking background actors to play Orcs and are urging the hairy, toothless and wrinkled among us to apply.An Orc is a fictional humanoid creature that is part of a fantasy race similar to goblins. In JRR Tolkiens books, they are depicted as ugly and filthy, with a taste for human flesh. They are fanged, bow-legged and long-armed.Two Auckland agencies have issued appeals to fill the roles in Amazons  billionproduction urging those under ft or over ft in with "wonderful noses", "character faces" and "hairy, hairy people of all ages and ethnicities" to sign up.Also being sought are "stocky, mean-looking bikers", "circus performers who can juggle" and anyone who boasts "natural red hair, white hair, or lots and lots of freckles". The fee is around pound per day.Do you know anyone who fits the bill  They could be looking back at you in the mirror. Although word to the wise: being an extra is a tough gig.Ive done it twice. The first was in the BBC drama Case Histories. I arrived on set in Edinburgh to interview the shows star Jason Isaacs. The actor, also an executive producer, extended an invitation to be in the background of a scene being shot in a seedy, underground bar.The crew were aghast, hearts visibly sinking at the thought of their carefully chosen, hipster extras being cast aside in favour of a dowdy writer pushing the wrong side of . But I did it anyway.The second time was in the comedy Still Game. Theres an episode, Balls Up, in the penultimate series where shopkeeper Navid Harrid, played by Sanjeev Kohli, makes an eyewatering, crunching tackle during a walking football tournament As hes sent off, Navid elbows his way through the gathered spectators, including me doing an uncanny impersonation of Edd Munchs The Scream as I hammily tried to convey shock, repulsion and pathos. Believe me, that acting lark is harder than it looks.Sitting uncomfortablyIF you happen to be ensconced on the loo reading this ndash either in paper or digital format ndash then brace yourself. The days of a comfy perch, as some are wont to think of the porcelain throne, could be numbered.A new toilet design has been unveiled with an upper surface that is tilted downwards at a -degree angle to increase strain on the legs, similar to doing a gentle squat thrust.: Susan Swarbrick: Pet portraits, erotic fiction and weird hotel theftsAccording to developers from the start-up company StandardToilet, the design makes it uncomfortable to spend more than five minutes on the toilet ndash a dehumanising gimmick being pitched at employers keen to improve workforce productivity.Talk about a slippery slope. Is nothing sacred  I will personally applaud anyone who comes up with a portable, cleverly shaped cushion to combat this abomination.

title: ado-coupe-new-sports-car-bringing-motor-manufacturing-back-scotland
story: By Sandra DickA rock-hard bench to sit on. No windows, no roof, no mirrors, not even a steering wheel and with brakes that were optional, signicantly raising the risk should the driver suddenly find themselves heading rapidly downhill.There was a high chance of breaking your wrist on the tiller and the wire wheels had a rather disturbing habit of buckling on corners, throwing the unfortunate occupants on to the road.Scotlandrsquos early motor cars may only have reached a less than hair-raising mph, but those who dared to climb into the rickety horseless carriage of an Argyll Voiturette were almost certainly in for the ride of their lives.It was early , and Scots were about to fall deeply in love with the thrills but hopefully not the spills of motoring, in vehicles carefully hand-built using the best of Scottish engineering skill and technology.Scottish car manufacturing ndash a stop-start affair at the best of times ndash ground to an emergency stop in  when the sprawling Linwood car plant, created in the sixties to churn out countless Hillman Imps, finally closed.Now, a group of Dundee-based motoring enthusiasts is set to relaunch Scottish car manufacturing, with the unveiling of a new sports car designed and built in the city.The lightweight fibreglass-bodied ADO Coupe takes its retro style from a  design for a sporty model intended to replace the iconic MG Midget but which never made it into production.Designed as a modern ldquogreen machine with plans for an electric engine and recycled structure ndash with options to upgrade the engine power for racing enthusiasts ndash the ADO Coupe is thought to be the first car to be made from scratch in Scotland since production halted at the Linwood site.The brainchild of car enthusiast Douglas Anderson, designer Richard Oakes and former Jaguar designer Clark Dawson, it will also become the first vehicle manufactured in Dundee.ldquoI think it is a work of art and pretty sensational, says Anderson, who dreamed of being a car designer since his youth but was thwarted by a lack of opportunities in the Scottish motor manufacturing sector.While the price hasnrsquot been revealed, each ADO Coupe will be built to order ndash not unlike the early Argyll, Albion and Arrol-Johnston horseless carriages which first introduced Scotland to the convenience, relative ldquocomfort and ease of motor car travel.It was, according to Bob James, a guide and research volunteer at Glasgowrsquos Riverside Museum, a fairly bumpy start and one which, unfortunately for those working in the sector, would struggle to really hit top gear.ldquoGlasgow was awash with great engineers, he says. ldquoBut Scotland was probably too far away from the main centres for car manufacturing to make much senseldquoEventually we were losing steel works, aluminium works and engineering skills.ldquoThere was the prospect of lorries having to drive  miles to deliver components to build a car here and the costs increased to a point where it didnrsquot make financial sense.And yet Scottish car manufacturing had set off at a roaring pace at the dawn of the th century when, inspired by the French motor vehicle market, the first all-Scottish cars slowly rolled off the production line.ldquoUntil then, government legislation had protected the toll road owners, the canals and railways which had lobbied strongly saying they couldnrsquot have cars on the road.ldquoThe French were well ahead of us, and there came a point when the British couldnrsquot ignore what was happening any longer, he adds.The change saw a mini-boom in Scottish car-making, led by the ldquoAs ndash Argyll, Arrol-Johnston and Albion, all Glasgow-based manufacturers which brought motorised vehicles to the nationrsquos streets.Leading the way was Springburn locomotive engineer George Johnston, and Forth Bridge engineer Sir William Arrol, who had the first British-built motor car ready to hit the road as the century drew to a close.The Arrol-Johnston six-seater ldquoDogcart, a wood-bodied vehicle started by the pull of a rope, rolled off the production line at a factory at Camlachie on a site close to Celtic Park in Glasgowrsquos east end.Arrol-Johnston vehicles were eventually found on roads around Britain. However, an unfortunate episode which saw its  Victory model sold to the Prince of Wales only to break down during a royal tour brought unwelcome publicity, and the firm folded in .Meanwhile, competition had come from rival Albion, formed in  by two former Arrol-Johnston engineers and with production beginning in a first-floor factory in Glasgowrsquos Finnieston Street. By , however, the business had shted to Scotstoun to cater for emerging demand for lorries and delivery vehicles.A more chequered future, meanwhile, awaited Argyll Motors.Launched in , its Argyll Voiturette was an almost identical copy of a Louis Renault motor car, painstakingly handmade at a former bicycle factory in Hozier Street, Bridgeton.ldquoIt was very basic and looked like a big pram on giant wheels with a very light metal chassis, adds Bob James.ldquoThe gear box, engine and wheels would be built and then it would be a case of finding a body to fit on it. That meant going to old carriage coachbuilders who would adapt horse-drawn coach and carriages to fit on top of the body.The result was a vehicle that occupants didnrsquot so much sit ldquoin but sit perched on top of, he adds.Not surprisingly, there were accidents. ldquoThe Western Infirmary archives have descriptions of ious injuries inflicted on people who had crashes in their cars, he continues.ldquoIt was very common for people to get badly hurt or killed when they were lsquoejectedrsquo from their car.ldquoThe wire wheels would bucklethe driver took a corner too hard and the passengers would be flipped out. Another common injury was caused by the tiller.Two upright rods which were used to steer, the tiller could easily sht suddenly and snap the unfortunate driverrsquos wrist.Argyll Motorsrsquo demise followed the decision to lavish money on the construction of a new factory in Alexandria. ldquoIt was a vast, palatial factory where they planned to build the best cars in the world, he adds.ldquoThey went all-out but while Argyll sold cars in Russia, Japan and Australia, they focused too much on the world market and didnrsquot look after their money.Eventually the expense of constructing the showpiece factory and a sht in demand saw the business stutter and close in .While other smaller manufacturers sprang up around the central belt, including the Madelvic Motor Carriage Company in Edinburgh ndash a specialist in electric vehicles, the derelict factory still stands today ndash none survived.And it would be decades before vehicle manufacturing on a signicant scale ed to Scotland.The pound million Rootes factory in Linwood began production of the Hillman Imp in  and employed over , people at the plant and surrounding suppliers.However, production of the rear-engine Imp ended in . The factoryrsquos new owners, Peugeot-Citroen, ordered its closure in .While a handful of kit car businesses exist, the ADO Coupe is thought to be the first Scottish-designed and manufactured vehicle for a generation.ldquoWe are starting small but we have already got a few customers and the first one should be on the road in early summer next year, adds Anderson. ldquoIt is a bit of a dream come true.The ADO Coupe is being developed at a workshop on the outskirts of Dundee with ious specialist elements of its manufacture to be sub-contracted to local and national suppliers.Its retro body is based on a  prototype sports car developed by BMC as a possible new style of MG Midget. However, the car, which featured a distinctive sloping back end, was never made.Prospective buyers of the Dundee-made ADO Coupe will be able to specy certain design elements, including interior, suspension and engine specications.The vehicle will be available as a road-going vehicle, or as a shell which can be adapted for the race-track. As well as being supplied ready-built, there are also plans to offer it in kit form for car-lovers to build themselves.The designers also have plans to explore using recycled materials to create the bodywork, and electric engines.

title: How Britain  woke  up in 2019     and what we saw wasn t nice
story: ldquoWoke only entered the Oxford English Dictionary last year as meaning ldquoalert to racial or social discrimination and injustice. Like its parent ldquopolitically correct, woke is a passion of the urban left. It is PC for the age of LGBTQIA+. suggested ldquowoke as word of the year, which arguably it should be, though not for the reason it thinks. For woke has changed meaning in the last  months, and become a term of derision, referring to a style of self-righteous, right-on thinking favoured by, well,columnists. It is now used to denote the metropolitan identity politics that contributed to Labourrsquos greatest defeat since the s.:Guy Stenhouse: Time to Get Over itNo-one is sure where the word ldquowoke came from, except that it emerged from African-American vernacular for ldquostaying alert, as in ldquostay woke, brother. In recent years it was adopted by the BlackLivesMatter movement with their hashtag #staywoke ndash meaning keeping black issues uppermost on social media.It was soon adopted by white millennials to emblemise not just racial awareness but a whole identitarian outlook on le. Woke expresses the ultra-feminist, multi-ethnic, gender non-conforming culture fashionable in American and UK campuses.Woke people love people of colour and loathe ldquostraight white males, ldquogammon and ldquoboomers. They adore so-called ldquonon-binary people who claim not to identy with any gender. No-one is quite sure what non-binary means. Do they swing both ways  No, thatrsquos bisexual. Are they transgender  Definitely not, and nor are they intersex. Itrsquos one of lersquos mysteries to many folk who are less woke.Wokeness has recently taken the media and advertising world by storm. Companies eager to keep up with the zeitgeist waste no chance to wave the rainbow flag and include multi-ethnic themes. This is sometimes called ldquowoke-washing. Every TV advert from McDonaldrsquos to John Lewis now has to feature a multi-racial family, asthe advertisers believe having two white people on one sofa is racism.The BBC drama Years And Years was kind of Woke Family Robinson. Black professhysional mother, transshygender daughter, gay cousin, asylum-seeker boyfriend, disabled sister ... all fighting the good fight against the emerging fascism of Brexit Britain. This compendium of woke identitarianism came complete with a middle-aged white dad. He naturally emerged as a morally worthless, adulterous creep, fit only to be punished by losing all his money.: Mark Smith: Happy Christmas First Minister ndash here are some questions I think you should answerWoke is easy to satirise and has been, mercilessly, by the comedian Andrew Doyle with his social media creation, Titania McGrath. She is a -year-old middle-class gender studies graduate, obsessed by her imagined victimhood, who identies as an ecosexual, non-binary person of colour and fights for social justice by writing bad poetry. ldquoThe only thing thatrsquos white about me, says Titania, ldquois my skin.She firmly believes women can have penises and that people should have electronic chips inserted in their brains to report heterosexual thinking. Men who have sexual dreams are guilty of rape, according to Titania.Woke folk thought Titania was the product of the homophobic, alt-right, fascist MSMndash or did until her creator, a gay Labour voter, was exposed last year. She is one of the great satirical creations of the century, just donrsquot expect Doyle to get invited on to The Mash Report.Woke is no joke. The leftrsquos penchant for strict identity politics, and the exotic fringes of LGBTQIA+ has had political consequences. The social media assault on ldquowhite working-class Brexit voters as racists and bigots was a factor in the alienation of traditional Labour constituencies. People in Bolsover, Workington and Sedgefield donrsquot much like being portrayed as fascists. Who knew There is a sanctimoniousness and intolerance about woke culture that is itself sometimes redolent of the authoritarian right, especially its approach to language. Anyone who mistakenly says ldquocoloured people instead of ldquopeople of colour, for example, will be ostracised. Pronouns must be obeyed. Feminist academics are no-edthey question whether transwomen are biologically female.Barack Obama warned the Democratic Party to avoid this ldquowoke politics with its ldquocancel culture. This is the practice of social justice warriors on Twitter demonising anyone who fails to conform to their particular form of non-conformism. If Trump wins again, it will in part because the Democrats havenrsquot listened.There is an anti-science, quasi-religious aspect to woke. Woke biology insists that sex is not innate but is ldquoattributed at birth ndash asevery child is born transgender. During the General Election campaign, the Liberal Democrat leader Jo Swinson tried, with disastrous results, to defend the woke dogma that biological sex doesnrsquot exist.Woke wars are raging in the Scottish National Party and have been since Nicola Sturgeon declared her support for self-ID ndash a law change to allow transgender people to self-identy as women without the need for medical intervention or convincing evidence that they have lived as women.There has been a vigorous reaction against this from feminists in and out of the SNP. They fear womenrsquos refuges, changing rooms and prisons are liable to be invaded by men declaring themselves to be female. They also resent being called ldquocis by wokeasians, aswomen are merely a subset of their own sex.The General Election has not caused any obvious soul-searching among the woke cadres. Indeed, the verdict ofwriter Paul Mason was a pitch-perfect expression of the woke worldview. The election was, he declared, ldquoa victory of the old over the young racists over people of colour selfishness over the planet.Such is the firm belief of the morally superior who spend their lives in an echo chamber saving the world from imagined hate crimes. It will take more than a landslide defeat to persuade them otherwise.
